p: At that time, Hamburg was (and still is) a boomtown of commerce, trade, and shipping. The consequences of the cholera outbreak were substantial: hysterics if not outright panic gripped the city, schools were closed, gatherings canceled, traffic from and to Hamburg stopped, and industrial production was brought to a halt. It took some time to get back to normal. It is worth remembering that cholera was never fully eradicated and, since 1961, remains classified as a pandemic, albeit “only” persisting in the resource‐poor settings of Africa and Haiti 4, regions with limited access to clean water.
